div1.head: Military Orders for Adolph F. Springer, October 25, 1901
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 61 - 1901
Springer

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 234. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, October 25, 1901.

1. Leave of absence for one (1) month, with permission
to go beyond the limits of the Department, is hereby granted
to Colonel T. A. Baldwin, 7th Cavalry.

2. The commanding officer, Columbia Barracks, Cuba,
will send, under proper guard, the following named general
prisoners, now in confinement at that post, together with
all papers relating to the prisoners, to Cabaña Barracks,
Havana, Cuba, to be turned over to the commanding officer
thereat, awaiting transfer to Fort Columbus, New York
Harbor:
William Beller, late private troop I, 7th Cavalry;
William A. Hawkes, late private troop G, 2d Cavalry;
James P. Thornton, late private troop L, 2d Cavalry;
John Sandquist, late private company I, 1st Infantry.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

3. Under authority of the Acting Secretary of War, dated
August 17, 1901, the following named general prisoners are
hereby transferred to Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
to serve out the remainder of their sentences as published
in the orders set opposite their respective names, viz.:

James P. Thornton, late private troop L, 2d Cavalry, sen-
tence published in paragraph 8, Special Orders No. 99,
series of 1900, Department of Matanzas and Santa Clara,
and paragraph 3, Special Orders No. 30, series of 1900, De-
partment of Cuba;

James L. Collins, late private 22d company, Coast Artil-
lery, sentence published in paragraph 3, Special Orders No.
104, current series, these Headquarters.

The commanding officer, Cabaña Barracks, will send the
prisoners, together with all papers relating to them, under
proper guard, to Fort Columbus, New York Harbor, so as
to arrive there not later than November 8, 1901, to be
turned over to the commanding officer thereat.

Upon completion of this duty the guard will return to
its proper station.

The Quartersmaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and the Subsistence Department travel
rations for the necessary number of days.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

4. Private Adolph F. Springer, Hospital Corps, U. S.
Army, now on duty at Las Animas Hospital in this city,
in connection with the investigation for the prevention of
yellow fever, being no longer required, will, in compliance
with paragraph 6, Special Orders No. 176, current series,
Headquarters of the Army, proceed to join his proper sta-
tion at the Medical Museum, Washington, D. C., reporting
upon arrival to the officer in charge for duty.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and the Subsistence Department will
commute his rations, in advance, at the authorized rate, for
one (1) day involved by delay at New York City and the
travel by rail.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Captain 7th Cavalry,
Adjutant General.
